body:
That is a good idea.  Do you have a link to a doc where Amazon state that 50GB is the limit - I can't seem to find a definitive answer.

Thanks for the suggestion and glad you like rclone!

Well, it's somewhere in the last three days of Googleing to find a good command line sync utility :-)

Here's what I know:
I was using GoodSync initially - a GUI based solution that was throwing errors on large files. I'm running that again to see if I can catch the exact error. I'm also testing a 68GB file on the Amazon Desktop App as well.

Here's the output from rclone at 99% copy complete on a large file of 68GB

---

Transferring:
-                             BackupHistory.tgz: 77% done. avg: 3203.9, cur: 10436.1 kByte/s. ETA: 28m0s
-  Google Drive/Google Drive backup 2014-10.zip: 99% done. avg: 3549.0, cur: 8952.9 kByte/s. ETA: 20s

2015/11/14 00:42:00 pacer: Rate limited, sleeping for 430.193442ms (1 retries)
2015/11/14 00:42:00 Google Drive/Google Drive backup 2014-10.zip: Received error: HTTP code 500: "500 Internal Server Error", reponse body: {"message":"Internal failure"}

##  - retrying 1/10

Here again after getting to 100% of another large file:

---

Transferring:
-                             BackupHistory.tgz: 100% done. avg: 3678.5, cur: 3038.1 kByte/s. ETA: 0s
-  Google Drive/Google Drive backup 2014-10.zip: 39% done. avg: 11407.1, cur: 16208.0 kByte/s. ETA: 41m11s

2015/11/14 01:20:35 pacer: Rate limited, sleeping for 552.437724ms (2 retries)
2015/11/14 01:20:35 BackupHistory.tgz: Received error: HTTP code 500: "500 Internal Server Error", reponse body: {"message":"Internal failure"}

##  - retrying 1/10

And again with the first file as it was tried again (some hours later):

---

Transferring:
-                             BackupHistory.tgz: 41% done. avg: 8503.1, cur: 9268.1 kByte/s. ETA: 1h21m22s
-  Google Drive/Google Drive backup 2014-10.zip: 100% done. avg: 10798.5, cur: 10758.0 kByte/s. ETA: 0s

2015/11/14 02:24:46 pacer: Rate limited, sleeping for 1.579800709s (3 retries)
2015/11/14 02:24:46 Google Drive/Google Drive backup 2014-10.zip: Received error: HTTP code 500: "500 Internal Server Error", reponse body: {"message":"Internal failure"}
- retrying 2/10
  2015/11/14 02:24:47 acd: Saving new token in config file
  ---

It's a lousy error from Amazon!

I'm sorry to give you such a difficult, well, time consuming, issue as it takes a good hour to copy that amount of data.

I'll check back in with the results of the desktop app and GoodSync big file copy to see what they report.

MPT
Update: Amazon Cloud App: It did the same, copied 68GB then, just started again.

Here is the best statement from Amazon that I've found [about the 50GB limit](https://forums.developer.amazon.com/forums/thread.jspa?threadID=4610)

You could use `--max-size=50GB` on the command line to get rclone to skip these files which would be a workaround. 

Rclone can upload files bigger than 10GB but it has a problem downloading them at the moment -  see #204

Update: GoodSync failed to copy up a large file (128GB) with this error:

2015-11-14 13:35:02: == Sync Started by Analyze And Sync Command
2015-11-14 13:35:02: File Systems limited number of parallel threads to 4
2015-11-14 13:35:02: Start only 1 threads, limited by tasks to run
2015-11-14 22:08:31: Copy New '/Users/michael/tmp/bigfile128' -> 'amazoncd://drive.amazonaws.com/test/bigfile128'
- ERROR: Copying file: Server says: Bad Request (status code 400): Cannot complete upload
  2015-11-14 22:08:32: Reconnected Folders in the main Sync thread after >= 30 min of inactivity
  2015-11-14 22:08:34: == Sync Complete. Time: 08:33:32, Speed: 4.3 MB/s, OK: 0, Errors: 1
  2015-11-14 22:08:34:

What I can do is put a 50GB max size for transfer in the acd remote.  This will give an error when you try to upload/download a file of that size.  I'd probably control that with a flag `--acd-max-size` which defaults to 50GB.

To not see the error and have a clean sync you'd need to use the `--max-size=50GB` command line option (the error it returns could suggest that).

What do you think?

(See also my previous comment)

I'm getting nervous now as, there's supposed to be a 10GB max download size and I've been able to download bigger files and, reading the developer forum indicates that Amazon is constantly working to increase file size limits. Ideally, they should (we should lobby them to) include a max file size indicator in the API so that you can build to that.

Any flag you put in today could be invalidated tomorrow - especially since the Amazon app fails as well, it may be a legitimate bug. Perhaps, if an upload fails with a 500 error at the end, it should be marked and not re-tried - the issue that I had was that rclone would retry again, effectively wasting many hours.

For now, perhaps a warning in the release notes and I'll using your existing  --max-size=50GB flag. Thoughts?
FYI, I found the reference to the 50GB limit - https://github.com/yadayada/acd_cli

issue.title: Document workaround for ACD maximum file size.

repository.name: rclone
repository.description: "rsync for cloud storage" - Google Drive, S3, Dropbox, Backblaze B2, One Drive, Swift, Hubic, Wasabi, Google Cloud Storage, Azure Blob, Azure Files, Yandex Files

issue.body:
There is no real good solution to failures from hitting the maximum file size on ACD.

Instead of hard-coding a fixed value, that may change, we show a warning in verbose mode and document workaround for ACD maximum file size.

Fixes #215.

body:
Btw. I tried to find the actual maximum today, but didn't find the exact value.

I tested:
- 50 GiB – 408 and never appeared (same amount of bytes as `--max-size 50G`)
- 49 GiB – 408 and never appeared
- 50 GB (46.566 GiB) – worked (408 and appeared after ~15min)
- 50 GB + 1 Byte – worked (408 and appeared after ~15min)
- 50,000 MiB (48.828 GiB) – worked (408 and appeared after ~15min)
- 50,000 MiB + 1 Byte – worked (408 and appeared after ~15min)

So the actual limit appears to be somewhere between 50 GB and 49 GIB.

I did give up after spending around 600 GB of intra region traffic…
@felixbuenemann nice one. Fancy sending a pull request to adjust the values in 4ce2a84?
Yes, I can do that. I should run at least a second test at the 50 GiB and 49 GiB values, to make sure it wasn't coincidence that those files didn't appear.

I checked with the Mac client and it limits the file size to exactly 50,000 MiB so we should use the same limit. I also had a failed upload when trying rclone copy with a 48.91 GiB file.

I'll open a PR shortly.

issue.title: Fix ACD file size warning limit

repository.name: rclone
repository.description: "rsync for cloud storage" - Google Drive, S3, Dropbox, Backblaze B2, One Drive, Swift, Hubic, Wasabi, Google Cloud Storage, Azure Blob, Azure Files, Yandex Files

issue.body:
The previous value of 50 GiB was too high, wee need to use 50,000 MiB.

For detailed discusssion see issue #215.

issue.body: When rclone is installed on a system with a bad connectivity where connections go down from time to time, could be perfect if rclone could do small incremental syncs of big files like rsync does so the file could be uploaded/downloaded in small chuncks.

issue.title: Sync transfers a lot more data than file sizes?

repository.name: rclone
repository.description: "rsync for cloud storage" - Google Drive, S3, Dropbox, Backblaze B2, One Drive, Swift, Hubic, Wasabi, Google Cloud Storage, Azure Blob, Azure Files, Yandex Files

issue.body:
Hello,

I am using rclone v1.33 with the crypt feature on amazonclouddrive.
Running on raspberry Pi 3 with raspian.

I started a rclone sync of one directory containing 10 big files (from 5M to 80G), together about 170GB. My upstream speed is just 10Mbit/s, so I know it will take longer. But it is running for days now and it should be already finished. One file is left and still being uploaded (the big 80G file).
The curious thing is that rclone gives me the status every minute like:

`Transferred:   433.574 GBytes (1.105 MBytes/s)
Errors:                 0
Checks:                 2
Transferred:            7
Elapsed time:  111h38m9.9s
Transferring:
-                           Zenbook_home.tar.xz: 58% done. avg: 1125.8, cur: 1133.1 kByte/s. ETA: 8h51m2s
  `

The speed looks okay, but why Transferred:   433.574 GBytes ?
The file to upload are just 170GB. What is this "Transferred" value telling me?

Armin
